segments.en: Linked Discourses 21
1. Monks
11. With Mahākappina
At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākappino yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then Venerable Mahākappina went to see the Buddha.

segments.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ mahākappinaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
segments.en: The Buddha saw him coming off in the distance,
and addressed the mendicants:

segments.pli: “passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, etaṃ bhikkhuṃ āgacchantaṃ odātakaṃ tanukaṃ tuṅganāsikan”ti?
segments.en: “Mendicants, do you you see that monk coming—white, thin, with a pointy nose?”
“Yes, sir.”
“That mendicant is very mighty and powerful. It’s not easy to find an attainment that he has not already attained.

segments.pli: Na ca sā samāpatti sulabharūpā yā tena bhikkhunā asamāpannapubbā.
Yassa catthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti tadanuttaraṃ brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
segments.en: And he has realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lives having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
segments.en: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
“The aristocrat is best of those people
who take clan as the standard.
But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct
is best of gods and humans.
The sun shines by day,
the moon glows at night,
the aristocrat shines in armor,
and the brahmin shines in absorption.
But all day and all night,
the Buddha shines with glory.”

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha describes Venerable Mahākappina as thin, fair-skinned, with a big nose—and as awakened.
